description:
A children's game from ELC. Very similar to Monkeying Around. Spin the spinner to see how many of your monkeys you may hang on the palm tree (or if you must hang one of the heavy gorillas instead). Think before you place your monkeys because, if you are not careful, the tree will collapse and the monkeys will tumble into the crocodile infested pond below. First one to hang all their monkeys on the tree wins.

Similar to:

    Hanging Monkies
    Monkeying Around

Comes with 4 double sided game boards (9 pictures of animals on one side, 9 animal names on the other allowing non-readers to play against readers), some counters and a tape of animal sounds. Start the tape anywhere then put a counter on your game board whenever you recognise the call of one of your animals. First person to complete their board wins.

Focus is a trivia game quite similar to Trivial Pursuit. It contains 400 cards with total of 2400 questions in six categories: miscellaneous, science and nature, entertainment, sports and leisure, geography and history.

Collect a token from each category to win.

Babble is an electronic sound reversal game.  The players take turns pushing the Record button to record a target word or phrase into the Babble game outside of earshot of the other players.  Then the other players take turns attempting to guess the target phrase correctly.  First they push the Play button which plays the target phrase backwards.  They can do this a few time then they must push the Mimic button and attempt to speak the backwards phrase as close as they can.  The Babble game then immediately speaks the mimicked phrase backwards which, if the player did a good job, should sound like the original target phrase.  The player then guesses the target.  If they are wrong the next player takes a turn.  If they are correct the round is over and the next player records a new target phrase.

(From the publisher's website)

Scrapyard 500 is a fast-paced road race game in which players "build" race buggies, load them with weapons and compete in a no-holds-barred race around the Scraptown track. Playable either with the counters included in the rules or with 28mm scale miniatures and 1/35 scale vehicles, Scrapyard 500 offers five character types to choose from in building a race team, six weapons (everything from net guns for the pacifists to flame throwers and rocket launchers for those of a more lethal persuasion) plus a hex-based, build-it-yourself track that includes nine different hazard hexes that can be used to make a different track for each race. Rules are easy to learn and offer endless chaos and laughs. Remember, it's not how you win the race. It's winning that counts.

From the Publisher:

Time Blocks is a block stacking game that will surely challenge the whole family. It is fast paced and will summon your powers of shape and color recognition, not to mention building skills. Flip over a card, find the correct blocks and replicate the structure shown. But hurry... you only have a minute and some of the configurations are devilishly difficult to build. Younger children can play the game by duplication the pattern on the card flat on the table top. Game includes 28 hardwood colored blocks, 1 sand timer and a deck of 100 game cards."

Ages 7 to adult

Box has sticker on it stating "excellence in family issues - child's best toys - Child Magazine. (no year given)

3 possible moves:
- Move or insert 1 of your stones
- Move 1 part of the board.
- Rotate 1 part of the board

The starting formation for the board is a square and all 4 tiles had to be connected all the time (at least touching edge by edge). The goal of the game is to get 6 stones in a row.

Treasure, tricks or trouble - is this your lucky night?

Atmosfear: Khufu - The Mummy is an amplified experience in home entertainment.  With its unique combination of board game and interactive DVD, this game of chance and skill is a race against time.  Once you press play you only have 45 minutes to lay down all your scarabs then take on the Great Pharaoh himself in Khufu's ultimate challenge.

Race around the board to collect treasures, and face the challenges in each of the four Chambers of the Great Pyramid, where fortunes are won and lost at the roll of the dice.

With interactive game play, random selection that ensures a different game every time, and awesome atmospheric digital surround sound and picture, this speedy, spooky, spectacular DVD board game promises hours of fun and laughter for players 12 years and over.

So come on in and match wits with your host, the fiendish pharaoh Khufu.  He really wants you to win!

Or does he...??

From the box:
"A fascinating quiz game"
"An "I.Q." game for family parties"

Contents are 12 Quiz cards of four types, each appearing three times.  Each card has five puzzles (number sequence, missing-letters, pattern-recognition, anagram and general knowledge).

Probably this game is from the 1950s, though there is no date on the box or answer sheet.

The box is marked 'Series 3' and it seems there were several editions containing different puzzles. Certainly the replay value seems small for this on its own.

Discover your fate on the road to stardom! Like the original Game of Life Game, you start with Career or School Stage. Careers include TV Personality, Movie Director, Model, Pop Star, Film Star and Soap Star. Spin the wheel to see which career you belong to, whether you pay a large fortune or small fortune, how much space you move (including -2) and whether everyone moves forward or backwards... Be the highest earner at the end of the game to win!!!

A collection of three activities designed to test your musical knowledge.

Chart Toppers- Guess the decade that a song debuted.
Lyriculous-name a song using only the new lyrics provided.
Bubba-Lips-name a song by humming melody while putting a finger across lips rapidly.

Team Game, with 10 rounds.

"The object of the game is for each player to cover all the circular openings in his section with Topper pieces. EVERY PLAYER PLAYS ON EACH SPIN.
If the color black appears in the section of the player who has just turned the spinner, he can demand that one of the other players remove a Topper piece. from this section as a penalty."

From the box:

Hammy and Stella are stocking up for winter by gathering all the food they can for hibernation. But suburbia is not always forest friendly -- there are scary sprinklers, SUVs and scouts to avoid. Players help them make their way "Over the Hedge" and around suburbia by collecting food tokens. The first friend to collect all seven food tokens wins the game! Contents: 1 Game Board, 1 Die, 4 Play Pieces: RJ, Verne, Stella & Hammy. 35 Suburbia Cards, 28 Food Tokens, & Instructions.

Strategy Seven is a new, single and multi-player "puzzle board game" that will put your logical deduction and memory skills to the test. With millions of variations, you will never have to play the same game twice!

Strategy Seven can be played as a single or multi-player game. It is a unique game that can be tailored to increase the level of difficulty to suit the player/s. Each game includes three Code discs ranging in difficulty from level 1 to level 3. There are additional "Collectors" Code discs available (from level 3 to level 7).

You can increase or decrease the difficulty of each game by choosing various ways of setting up the board. The markers can all be placed on the board with the colored sides facing up to play an easier game. For a more challenging game, the markers can be placed on the board with the numbered sides facing up.

The objective of the game is to re-arrange moving pieces, by rotating the center code disc, to enable you to move desired components to their correct locations.

Home Page: http://www.stencils.co.za/Strategy.htm

Follow Paul on his three missionary Journeys. Test your knowledge and learn more about the Bible as you reinforce positive Christian values and provide lots of fun for all. Third in the Bible Journeys series. Ages 8 and up. Includes game board, playing pieces, and question cards.

Breitenfeld is a Tactical level board-wargame which covers the 17th Century battle between the Swedes and the Imperials, near the Saxony city of Leipzig.

It was published in Panzerfaust Magazine Volume 5 #3 in July 1970.

Components: 

    Rules booklet
    Map in four 8.5" X 11" sheets
    Counters are on one unmounted sheet printed in three colors.

Game published in 1897 by the Rhode Island Game Company.

The object of the game is to capture with the small discs or men the ships and territory of the opposing player.

The game board features spots for Admiral Dewey, Admiral Sampson, Admiral Cavery and Admiral Motijo and spaces for Torpedo, Short on Coal, Out of ammunition and Mines. The board is divided with each side in possession of half at the beginning. Object of the game is to take over all of the opposing men

The game board also features drawings of famous ships that actually took part in the War. American Cruisers; Vesurtux, Olympia & Brooklyn along with Battleships; Massachusetts, Oregon and Iowa.

Players have 10 men and a Flagman who move depending on a spin, but once a piece crosses into the other players territory that piece is moved either left or right depending on whether or not the roll was odd or even.  When a man stops on a square marked Mine, Torpedo or Out of Ammunition in an enemy territory he must return to his side of the board.

A game created in 1943 in order to help Americans deal with the fact that rationing of goods was needed in order to win the war!

Players start at home and then travel along a much traveled route applying for Ration Cards at the Ration Board. Players are liable to meet many obstacles along the way. Luck and skill are important factors in players acquiring their ration cards. Numerous helpful as well as hindering elements that make the trip a most exciting experience can to a certain degree be determined by the players themselves but others are left to chance. As is natural during the present emergency, the players will take these encounters in stride like the good American he/she is.

Each time around the board the person stops at a different Ration Board and tries to acquire a different ration card by fulfilling different requirements; BUTTER roll a 5 or a DOUBLE, SUGAR roll an 8 or a 2 or a 12 etc.  The first player to acquire 5 ration cards and return home is the winner.

The game board is a road winding through the countryside and suburbs to a city where the Ration Boards are stationed and then back again to home.

Additional info: Contained 8 wooden car pawns and 2 wooden dice, and was "item number 432" from Jayline Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia, PA.

Party game where each player secretly selects 6 words among tens listed on the Argument card received at game start.  Then at his own turn, the player starts to show just the first letter of each word. Other players secretly write down their guess, then the second letter is revealed, then third and fourths ones. Points are assigned depending on which round (1 to 4 letters revealed) you have written the right word.

A precis of the rule’s introduction.

These rules are intended for use with one infantry section (usually 10 men), in 54mm scale, per player, which attacks a small objective such as a machine gun bunker or defended house (Airfix Strongpoint). Start with the basic rules, and when you have mastered these add some or all of the more realistic advanced rules. You can use any scale, of course - half all distances for 25mm scale, and if you insist on fighting Stalingrad in a matchbox an the 10.30 from Paddington, divide distances by 10 and use 5mm figures! As is inevitable, this has escalated to whole platoons (often still with one player per section) with some support such as a medium machine gun team or man-pack flamethrower team per side. We've never bothered very much about a points system, though one is included in the appendices to these rules, except that men defending a strong position such as a farmhouse should be attacked by about twice their number. Favourite games include two units of 10 partisans each, ambushing a German staff car with escort of two motorcycle combinations and a section in a half track, and a British Recce unit consisting of a turret less Stuart tank, a Dingo scout car and a half-track with infantry section running into a German advanced defence unit in slit trenches with MMG's and Panzerfausts. The possibilities are enormous, and great variety can be achieved quite cheaply, using Britain’s or Airfix figures and vehicles, which are less prone to damage than Tamiya and other plastic models, though we use these too!

Each soldier must have the correct rank, weapons and equipment, a limited supply of ammunition (so that he can run out!) and is identified by a number on his base. This number ensures that each man stays with his correct unit - if he's more than 20cm. from it, he has deserted! Wounds are NOT bullet wounds - you don’t go anywhere with a bullet, in you, no matter WHAT John Wayne gets up to! Wounds restrict a man's fighting ability, and may eventually prevent him from fighting, though he may recover in time for a later round if you are fighting a campaign.

This is a card game by Joe Magic Games. The game is played with two custom decks of playing cards with renaissance art depicting medieval England. Kingdoms are set up on mats that define each player's domain.  Players attempt to manipulate the cards which represent different aspects of the court, including kings, queens, assassins, and spies.  They also manage population, treasury, and war.  
The game includes pawns that indicate level of royalty, and advancement cards like: Longbow, Sanitation, and Chivalry.  Also, mixed in with the cards are events like Corruption, Peasant Revolt, and Black Death. The player who is the current ruler has the ability to tax and forbid other players to perform particular actions.  In this way, that player has more control over events, but also is a bigger target for war and assassination.
The winner is the player who manages to survive two rounds by either having the only living population or being the ruler and only player with cards.

Card game. Simulates the siege of the Alamo in 1836.

Players will have to make their own sets of cards.
The Texans and Mexicans have their own unique decks.

Instructions are included to be able to play solitaire.

A game that attracted little attention when it was published in the eighties, despite the reputation of its designer. The concept was developed by French essayist Guy Debord (1931-1994) in 1965, but not published for many years. Debord described himself as a filmmaker, but he is known as the founder and one of the most important members of the Situationist International, a small band of avant-garde artists and revolutionaries. One key concept of their theory is the spectacle: the image replaces substance and modern capitalist society is a society of "spectacular" commodity consumption. Having long been treated as a producer, the worker is now courted and seduced as a consumer.

In 1977, Debord created a small publishing company named "Les Jeux Stratégiques et Historiques" with French movie producer Gérard Lebovici. The first game was Debord's "Le Jeu de la Guerre", but only 4 prototypes are produced. The game was published as a book, with a map, rules and detailed descriptions in 1987. (Lebovici had been mysteriously shot in a parking lot in Paris by this time). In 1991, Guy Debord decides to insist that all his movies & books be destroyed. It is also the fate of his book/game. Debord committed suicide in 1994. Nevertheless during the '90s, his work gains more and more influence. The book/game is published again in 2006 by French publisher Gallimard (price: 18 €), but it's only a book (in French), co-signed by Debord's lifetime partner Alice Becker-Ho.

The game uses a mapboard containing 500 squares (25 x 20) divided in two by a border line. Each territory has 2 arsenal squares, 3 fortress squares, and 9 mountain squares (blocking movement,shooting and communication lines). Setup of units (infantry, cavalry, artillery, horse artillery) is free and secret. At his turn, each player may move up to 5 units and/or attack. Aim of the game is to completely destroy the enemy or conquer his 2 arsenals. No dice: combats are resolved taking into account the attack/defense ratios of the opponents (unit retreats from -1, and is destroyed from -2) Communication lines are critical.

The English translation published by Atlas has a faulty translation of the rules, making it more or less unplayable.

Doubly licensed Full Thrust variant stand alone for the Traveller RPG's setting universe. Licensed by GZG and Far Future Enterprises.

Mechanics are adapted from and distinct from Full Thrust, specifically to capture the feel of small line vessel combats in the Traveller universe.

from the BITS page:
Power Projection: Escort focuses on the smaller, non-capital ships of the Traveller universe. These are the ships smaller than 10,000 tons with no spinal mounts. The game includes two sheets of black and white counters, 14 Zhodani and Imperial ship designs and a number of scenarios. It is full compatible with Power Projection: Fleet and has 12 ship designs which aren't included in that book.

ISBN 1-901228-31-2, 30 pages, A4 format, written by Dominic Mooney. Cover by Jesse DeGraff. © 2002.

Get Rollin! is a dice rolling game.  Each of the four players has an eight space track on the board, a playing piece and five six-sided dice.  A large bell is placed in the center space of the board.  The leader for a round rolls one die to determine the target number.  Immediately after that all players begin rolling all of their dice as fast as possible.  Any time a player rolls the target number they must place any dice with that number in the center of the board and call out how many dice along they are toward getting all five with the target number.  They then continue to roll the rest of their dice.  When a player gets all five of their dice to match, they ring the bell and win the round moving one space on their track.

Old Mr. Holmes of Homesville, a very rich man living about 20 miles from the Village of Spruceville, having taken suddenly ill sends his colored boy (I know that this is politically incorrect but the rules do in fact state that and for completeness I have included it) Tom to the village to summon a doctor. Several Doctors head for Homesville and the game is based on their journey.

Each player takes one piece to represent a doctor. Each player spins the indicator in turn and beginning at the Doctor's Office heads forward toward Homesville. The object is to arrive there by exact count. Along the way the Doctors will be affected by squares that they land on. "Doctor meets Mr Smith who hurt himself. Doctor and Mr.Smith must both go back to the office." or "Doctor finds he has lost his medicine and must return to the Eight Mile House to look for it" or "Doctor's horse runs away and Doctor  must return to Mr. Jones' residence" or "Doctor's carriage breaks down and he must return to the Blacksmiths Shop for repairs". The Doctor who arrives at the Homesville site first by exact roll wins the game.

Dino Trivia is jam-packed with questions and quirks about dinosaurs!  Amaze your friends when you know the answer to: "Where was the first Velociraptor fossil found?"  If you are a junior player, do you know the answer to "What did a T-Rex eat?"  When you cannot answer some questions correctly, you might be asked to perform an outrageous action and pretend you are an Allosaurus chasing your prey!!!

[Text from back of box]

Players take turns asking the person to their left questions from the back of the next card drawn from the pile.  Standard questions may be quite difficult, even for an adult, while "junior" questions are very simple to accommodate younger players.  A correct answer earns the player the card while an incorrect answer may require them to perform an "outrageous action," such as flapping their arms like a Pteranodon.

The winner is the first to construct a T-Rex skeleton composed of four separate images on the backs of the cards they earn.  Obviously many cards contain duplicate images, so reaching this goal may require more than four correct answers.

All information is taken from the book Dinosaurs by Michael and Caroline Carroll; religious content is held to a minimum on the cards themselves (2 of 100 questions).

Questival is a trivia boardgame published in the Philippines.  Game components is composed of 2 dice, 1 hourglass, 8 plastic chips, play money, and a rule sheet.

Players are divided into two separate teams (Red and White) that must compete in answering questions from cards randomly drawn with the use of a dice.  There is a plastic hourglass included in the game to set a time limit on how long each team can answer a question.  Correctly answered questions allow that team to win play money and to have another turn.  So there can be a chain of turns for a team until a question has not been answered correctly and the time runs out.  The gameboard acts as a scoring track and for separating the question cards based on its points.  The team which earned the highest score and grabbed the most in prize money is the winner.

The 24 Countdown Game is based upon the popular Fox TV show "24".

The players are dealt eight cards. During this initial deal, one player is assigned the role of terrorist. There are twenty-four rounds of gameplay. Each round tells the players which suit must be played in order to win the trick. The Jack Bauer Card is wild and wins any trick. A player who wins a trick must either draw and keep two cards or draw and follow the instructions from the top card of the Action Deck.

The terrorist wins the game by not being eliminated and having the most points or by eliminating all the other players. Any other player can win by eliminating the terrorist or by having the most points.


        Note: This is essentially the same game as 24 Card Game, except that it uses a board for the timer, instead of sleeved card.
    


  Buy Microbadge - 24 fan

 Buy Microbadge - Kiefer Sutherland is a character Jack Bauer plays when he's not saving the world.

A music trivia game with 2 CDs and an electronic gizmo to record who buzzes in first.  There are also action rounds (mime playing the drums or sing a Paul Simon song) as well as "improvised trivia" - category plus first letter e.g. name a "band" starting with "S".

From the back of the box:

This exciting game has heaps of music on 2 CD's and provides hours of fun with electronic buzzers that you hit when you recognize the songs or the artist.  The disc jockey on the CD's will play music cuts from the 60's to the 90's, pop hits, rock and roll or themes from movies and TV shows.  When you think you know the name of the song or who the artist is, hit your buzzer and the electronic umpire will decide who got in first.  Even if your trivial knowledge is not up to scratch, playing an action card gives you a chance to gain points by putting on a mini-performance for your friends to enjoy.  When using the TMG Quiz cards you create thousands of questions and hours of fun calling for fast action on the buzzers and another chance to be a superstar.

3 Man Chess is played “in the round,” that is, the field of play is circular.  For the most part, 3 Man Chess is played just like conventional Chess. – there was NEVER any intention of trying to make the game “better” because that can’t be done. However, being able to play with three minds interacting creates situations that never arise in conventional Chess.


     3 Man Chess’ circular game board consists of 6 concentric ranks of 24 files and an open central “void” that pieces may pass, but not stop on. There are teardrop shaped curves drawn on the board to help diagonal moves navigate the “void.”
     3 Man Chess uses conventional chess teams (three of them!) – 16 pieces that follow all of their traditional rules; 8 pawns start on rank #2 protecting 2 rooks, 2 knights, 2 bishops, a queen and a king which start on rank #1 (the outermost rank).
     The teams are separated from each other by “moats” and “creeks” that are impassable at the start of the game.
     Diagonal moves follow the drawn guidelines, passing across the center to the opposite “spoke.”
     Straight moves may also pass across the central “void,” or move around the circular ranks.
     After just a couple of turns around the board, strategy becomes intensely complex and fascinating! An unexpected move might well result in a cascading massacre. Defense is crucial since a diagonal move through the center, or a horizontal move around the center can sneak up behind you. Your two opponents can team up to checkmate you, or ultimately you can checkmate both of them at the same time!


—description from the publisher

RINGMASTER - WAR FOR MIDDLE EARTH (2-6 players)

A free tribute to Tolkien and his battles in Middle Earth.
The game can be played in 3 ways: Basic, Advanced or Team.

BASIC GAME
During a battle, attacker calculates his Combat Value that is equal to the number of his armies involved in the battle. This value can be modified playing one or more cards.
Then, the defender calculates his Combat Value, adding the value of his own armies and cards. The higher score wins and inflicts casualties as the difference between the two values.
The game ends after 10 turns or if a player gains 10 Victory Points.

ADVANCED GAME
Players are divided into 2 factions (Alliance or Darkness Forces), trying to advantage or stop the journey of the Fellowship, using another set of special cards listing the major character of the Lord of the Rings. The movement of the Fellowship is managed by the Alliance players, while the Darkness forces will try to stop it.  Players can also recruit characters of the Fellowship, Nazguls, heroes or evil creatures, using them in a battle.

TEAM GAME
Allied players conduct battles as a team. Armies setup is predetermined.

HOW TO PLAY
RINGMASTER is a FREE game in pdf high-resolution. Print front/back the following 4 files. You need also some wooden cubes (or the Risk pawns) for the armies.

- Map (84x60 cm).
- Rules (14 pages)
- Battle Cards (64 cards)
- Event Cards (64 cards)

ENGLISH TRANSLATORS
Many thanks to: ROIG YVES (version 10.0), SEAN FORRESTER (version 9.0) and ANTONIO CHAVEZ (version 5.0).

Mundialito (Gold Cup) is an abstract strategy board game of movement and ball control whose objective is for you to score a goal (getting your ball to the last row) before your opponent. Move your pieces, push and jump over your opponent's pieces until you score a goal.

Ages: 7 and up, a game for children and adults.

Available:

http://www.labsk.net/index.php?topic=4157.0
http://icehouse.labsk.net
http://icehousegames.org/wiki/?title=Mundialito

This game is one of the finalists of the 2007 Concurs Ciutat de Granollers de creaciÃ³ de jocs.

This game was produced by Waddingtons Games for SKI (a British yogurt manufacturer) and was available by mail order from SKI.

The object of the game is to be the first team coach to get all four members of their team 'fit' by reaching 100 points on the SKI fitness scale. There are no dice; instead pieces are moved round the board according to the instructions of red movement cards. They gain or lose fitness depending on the blue activity cards drawn. Fitness is recorded on dials (SKI Fitness Scales).
Game published in Casus Belli n°68 and 69 covering Caesar's campaign in Gauls.

Kalevite Maa ("Land of Kalevs" in translation) is not sophisticated game yet it provides entertainment for parents and children alike. The object of the game is to be the first player to collect three items depicted on a secret quest card. The items - tokens with a picture of an item - are randomly distributed on the game board face down. Players take turns by moving their pawns on the board by one step. If the move ends on an unexplored token the player will claim the token unless the token is a monster in which case the monster has to be defeated first by rolling dice. Some items - sweets, to be precise - boost a player's speed or combat ability.

Kalevite Maa is a promotional boardgame. It is published by a sweets producer - "AS KALEV" - and 3/4 of the relatively large boardgame box is actually filled with sweets. Yet, it is an interesting and engaging game with components of outstanding quality.

The game covers the first disaster that befell U.S. cavalry when they tried to coerce the Indian tribes on Bozeman trail.

This would culminate in the Fetterman massacre which the Indians lured 80 U.S. cavalryman into a huge ambush consisting of 1000 Indian warriors.

Basically surrounded and overwhelmed U.S. troops with heavy firepower(Spencer and Martini henry repeating rifles and Sprinfield muzzle loaders) and limited ammo vs. hordes of Indians armed mostly with bow and arrow but also a smattering of repeating rifles and muzzle loaders.

Chit pull game system based on his design Into a Bear Trap.

One 11x17" color game map
Over 280 playing pieces
One Rulebook
Playing Aid Cards
Remember is a very simple Concentration type game using Slot Machine type symbols like Cherries, and Lemons and Bells. He/She who matches most WINS!

London, 1901. At the world famous Portobello Market, the goal in the morning is to secure the best places to build stalls. Try to place your stalls in the most lucrative manner, cut off your opponents, and grab the most profitable alleys for yourself. You can build only where the Bobby stands—but a little cash will make the Bobby stand where you want him to!

East India Railway was the prototype title for this game, and it became Portobello Market when published by Schmidt.

The Game of Life reworked into a party game for brides-to-be.

Players select and buy various wedding items (rings, cake, honeymoon package), while recording happiness points resulting from events leading up to the big day.

The blue color of your cape leaves an azure streak across the city skyline as you fly above the buildings on patrol. It has been a peaceful night over all, only one bank robbery, and that you stopped with the help of Kid Zip. The explosion rolling out of the building below you then breaks the silence. You watch with your super eyesight as the green color smoke rolls out of the window of one of Sonic Lab’s windows. You watch as Doctor Death leaps into the air from that very window, a beaker of the hyper explosive, chemical Y, tightly held in his armed fist. You thought he was still in jail, serving a 300-year sentence for his last attempt at destroying the city. With a sigh you dive into the coming fight, sure it will be another long night ahead. Who said being a super hero was all capes and fun.

Comic Book Heroes is a multi player card game where you take on the role of either a super powered hero or one of their many villainous foes. Streaking through the skies in your hyper jet boots, or crash through brink walls with your super strong muscles. All the thrills, excitement and goofy fun of classic comics are here within Comic Book Heroes. Struggle with and aid other players as they battle each other to see who will be the hero supreme.

So let the cosmic beams fuel your dreams of glory, the mutant genes turn you into a freak with a heart of gold or allow sinister plots to fill you with a destiny for glory and dominance of all mankind. Play Comic Book Heroes and live the adventure.

Each set comes with two characters, a hero and a villain with 18 cards for each. The set also comes with 18 common cards and 18 new common cards only available with that set, for a total of 72 cards per set.

From the Box:
"The Crime Club Party Game"
"Test Your Power of Observation"
"Photographic Clues - for the solution of each problem"

12 cards are included, three copies of four types. Each card bears a photograph of a crime scene and a description of Inspector Cameron interviewing a suspect.  Something in the picture reveals the suspect to be lying, and this is for the player (or team) to find.

Probably this game is from the 1950s, though there is no date on the box or answer sheet.

The box is marked 'Series 3' and it seems there were at least this number of editions containing different puzzles.

The general theme and mechanics of Caylus Magna Carta are similar to the Caylus board game. However, there is no board or score track and the tactical nuts and bolts of the game are somewhat different. In terms of components, the game consists of cards, money, worker pawns, resource markers, the provost, and castle building stones. Each player has a set of identical cards, which are shuffled and used as a face-down draw deck. Players start with an opening random draw of cards, and on his turn a player can either:


    extend the road by building a new building 
    pay 1 to draw a new building card 
    pay 1 to discard his hand and draw a fresh hand (with the discard deck being shuffled for a new draw deck once the draw deck is exhausted) 
    pay 1 to place a worker on one of the existing building cards 
    build one of the common prestige building cards (some of which are placed at the beginning of the game as part of the setup) or 
    pass


Once everyone has passed, the cards are resolved up to the provost (which can be moved in passing order by paying money).

Ownership of the non-common buildings is shown by the card color. When a worker is placed on a card, the owner earns either resources or money as a reward instead of victory points. Players may also choose to help build the castle. Starting with the first player to have passed, players can pay resources to obtain castle stones. The stones are worth three different values (2-4 points). Players collect the most valuable ones first. In addition, the player who collects the most building stones each round is rewarded with a gold resource marker.

From round to round, 1st player privileges rotate to the left, and the provost starts two cards further down the path from the castle.

The winner of the game is the player who has accumulated the most victory points once the game end has been triggered the turn the castle is finished. Victory points are awarded for castle stones, cards built, and resources and money in hand at the end of the game.

A free Engle Matrix Game posted on the Hamster Press website. The publisher's description:

"Welcome to the honorable society of war gamers. Our hobby has a long and noble past. Ever since Robert Lewis Stevenson (Treasure Island) and HG Wells (War of the Worlds) played games with toy soldiers in the 1890's, grown men have been reliving make believe glory in made up wars."

"'Politics by other means...' is a simple war game suitable for children and adults. It is not tied to one historical period. It covers all wars from Summeria to Star Wars. All you need to play are a few figures, some six-sided dice and a table of toy terrain to make a battle field. The game is played by each player, one at a time, moving and shooting. Everyone going ends the turn."

1/15/2007: The Living Earth Games website appears live, and Living Landscapes is available directly from the publisher as well as from a specific retailer in the UK: http://www.eco-logicbooks.com/index.cfm?fa=book_details&book_id=995

Previously:

Living Earth Games is a now defunct game company that made ecologically aware games printed in 100% recycled materials. The company appears to have been on the web until 2004.  The following information was on their website concerning Living Landscapes.

Living landscapes introduces in a playful way into the sometimes abstract relationships between the human needs and what you find in a rural landscape. Color frames around some card images distinguish the red human needs cards (food, shelter, climate regulation…) and the green cards that distinguish important landscape elements from the rest of the set. Laying down families of 3 or more cards (we give lists of examples), the players build up the design of a landscape and they can exchange cards between families.The game ends with a set of card families laid down as a draft landscape design.

Living Earth Games is a now defunct game company that made ecologically aware games printed in 100% recycled materials. The company appears to have been on the web until 2004.  The following information was on their website concerning Living Landscapes.

A game exploring the Water Cycle; each player represents a water droplet making it's way over the landscape, to the sea and into the air, interacting with the environment as it does so.

Epic strategy for 2-6 players. Players are controlling European empires. The goal of the game is too collect history point.

The box contains:
board (90x60cm)
54 action cards
6 empire cards
378 counters
money
rule book

Description with permission from www.boardgamenews.com-

"By airplane to Paris? By ship to Barcelona? Or by car or train to Milan? No matter how you do it, travel throughout Europe! With a good plan, the correct tickets, and some luck in your luggage, you'll lead a travel party to multiple destinations and use insider tips to make side trips. A slew of information in words and pictures for 155 cities is awaiting your visit!

The players travel by car, train, ship and airplane from city to city and control private and public destinations with three travel companies. The goal is to visit as many destinations as possible in six differently colored regions. Whenever a player reaches a destination, he lays the corresponding city card in front of himself. The game ends when a player has at least ten city cards (or nine cards with five or six players) in six different colors before himself, although the round is played to its end. The winner is the player who visited the most destinations in all six colored regions.

New game mechanisms: Europareise possesses novel game mechanisms that differ from the familiar travel games in the Ravensburger catalog (Deutschlandreise, Weltreise). Movement doesn't come from dice, but rather from tickets for planes, ships, trains, and cars. To keep the lines from tangling on the gameboard, no flight lines or ship lines are marked on the gameboard. The players travel from a ship's harbor with a ship chain to any harbor within reach of the ship chain. Travel by airplane is done similarly."

From the One Page Wars game series.

Up to six cars compete in a six lap race around an irregular oval track. Each car/driver counter is rated for speed, acceleration, and turning. The game focuses on making a successful die roll for each space through the corners. The cars may pass at will.

From the One Page Wars game series.

A simple, abstract game portraying a ground attack campaign by F-18 Hornets. "Goal: Defeat Somalian forces in a quick strike campaign. You play the 101st tactical ground attack. This unit is assigned to the USS Nimitz. While F-14's/EA-6's and other aircraft fly missions, you are assigned to take out ground targets around Somalia."
